title:
Multigraded Poincare series for mixed states of two qubits and the
  boundary of the set of separable states

title_detail.value:
Multigraded Poincare series for mixed states of two qubits and the
  boundary of the set of separable states

summary:
Let M be the set of mixed states and S the set of separable states of the
two-qubit system, and G = SU(2) x SU(2) the group of local unitary
transformations (ignoring the overall phase factor). We compute the multigraded
Poincare series for the algebra of G-invariant polynomial functions on the
affine space of all Hermitian operators of trace 1. We check that this series
is consistent with the list of invariants computed by Makhlin. By using the
recent result of Augusiak et al., we show that the boundary of S decomposes
naturally into two pieces. We prove that the part of this boundary which is
contained in the relative interior of M is a smooth manifold.

MULTIGRADED POINCARÉ SERIES FOR MIXED STATES OF
TWO QUBITS AND THE BOUNDARY OF THE SET OF
SEPARABLE STATES
DRAGOMIR Ž. –
D OKOVIĆ
Abstract. Let M be the set of mixed states and S the set of separable states
of the two-qubit system. Its Hilbert space is the tensor product H = C2 ⊗ C2 ,
and the group of local unitary transformations is G = SU(2) × SU(2) (ignoring
the overall phase factor). Let P be the algebra of real polynomial functions
on the space of all hermitian operators of trace 1 on H. Let P G ⊆ P be the
subalgebra of G-invariants. We compute its multigraded Poincaré series and
verify that it is consistent with Makhlin's list of 18 invariants. By using the
recent result of Augusiak et al. we describe the boundary of S and show that
its intersection with the (relative) interior of M is a smooth manifold.

Let P denote the algebra of real valued polynomial functions on H4,0 and P G
the subalgebra of G-invariant functions. Note that P G inherits the Z-gradation
from P. The homogeneous polynomials of P G may be used to construct measures
of entanglement of our quantum system.
The knowledge of P G is important because of the following well known fact:
Two states, say ρ1 and ρ2 , belong to different G-orbits iff there exists f ∈ P G such
that f (ρ1 ) 6= f (ρ2 ). If this holds true for a subalgebra A ⊆ P G , then we say that
A is complete.

Subsequently, Y. Makhlin [8] gave a simple construction of 18 invariants which
generate a complete subalgebra of P G . This subalgebra is proper and he gives
two additional invariants. However, it is still not established whether this enlarged
subalgebra is in fact the whole algebra P G . (According to M. Grassl [3] this can
be proved by using the relations for the invariant tensors of SU(2).)
As a complement to the two papers just mentioned, we compute in Section 2 the
Z3 -graded Poincaré series of P G . This multigraded series carries more information
about the invariants than the simply graded one.
Let us recall that a mixed state is called separable if it can be represented as a
convex combination of product states, and otherwise it is called entangled. Denote
by M the set of all states and by S the set of all separable states. It is well known
that these two sets are compact and convex, and have nonempty interior. By ∂M
resp. ∂S we denote the boundary of M and S, respectively.
In Section 3 we show that there is a natural way of decomposing the boundary ∂S
into two pieces. Each of these pieces is a portion of a real algebraic hypersurface
in the ambient affine space. In particular, it follows from our results that the
intersection of ∂S with the relative interior of M is a smooth manifold.

In a recent paper [1] Augusiak et al. have shown that S is exactly the set of
all states ρ satisfying the inequality det ρΓ ≥ 0, where Γ is the operator of partial
transposition, say with respect to the second party. Denote by D the real algebraic
hypersurface in the affine space (1/4)I4 + H4,0 given by the equation det ρ = 0. Its
image under Γ, which we denote by DΓ , is defined by the equation det ρΓ = 0.
Let us recall that ∂M consists of all ρ ≥ 0 (with trρ = 1) having at least one
zero eigenvalue, and so ∂M ⊆ D. This inclusion is in fact proper, i.e., ∂M is only
a small portion of the entire hypersurface D. By the Peres–Horodecki criterion [6]
we know that S = M ∩ MΓ . Hence, ∂S is the union of two pieces:

There are many papers devoted to the study of the geometry of the sets M and
S, e.g. [5, 7, 10, 12, 13, 14]. It may be of interest to study the boundary ∂S and
the determinantal hypersurface D in more detail. Let us say that a point ρ0 ∈ D is
smooth if the gradient ∇ det ρ does not vanish at ρ0 , and otherwise it is a singular
point of D.
The next proposition is valid for any n-dimensional complex Hilbert space H. In

Note that if n = 2 then it is impossible for both eigenvalues to be 0, which means

Let us return now to the case of two qubits. In that case we shall prove that the
piece DΓ ∩ M0 , where M0 denotes the relative interior of M, contains no singular
points of the hypersurface DΓ , i.e., for each ρ ∈ DΓ ∩ M0 , the operator ρΓ has
exactly one zero eigenvalue.
Theorem 3.3. The piece of the hypersurface DΓ contained in the (relative) interior
of M is smooth.
Proof. Assume that a point ρ0 ∈ DΓ ∩ M0 is a singular point of DΓ . Then ρΓ0 is a
singular point of D and so it has at least two zero eigenvalues. We shall now apply
an argument of Sanpera et al. [11]. By their Theorem 2, the zero eigenspace of ρΓ0
contains a product vector |e, f i, and obviously we have
